title: Bird Sun Boat Artwork for the Visually Impaired

description.text: 3D artwork of a bird, sun and boat for visually impaired people to touch and get a sense of the image. This kind of work is called a lithophane. This site will help you make your own, http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ . I did not know there were existing methods already when I made this and posted it on Reddit where lots saw it and made their own versions and a fellow Thingiverse user (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:818899) pointed me to the 3dp.rocks site.
123D design by Autodesk.

author: flycouch

description.text: these are the original goggles unmodified from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128963 . The trinket enclosure is from another user as well. This setup is meant to work with the adafruit neopixel goggle set. The gear i modeled to accept 2 52mm lens filters so it can work as a large lens. on my own i also added a wide angle filter. Anyway. All i made was the gear really. went for a Post Appocalyptic theme with the paint and wiring.

These are the steampunk goggles by guyc. I used the krylon hammerred finish types of paint in layers to achieve the base coat of paint. started out with a good multi coat of flat black primer. then used model paints to do detail work.

The strap is made of leather. I also do leather work. I attached the strap with 1/8th inch shock cord doubled up to give it elasticity. I used this kit to do the lights https://www.adafruit.com/products/2221

author: CrazySaidWhat

description.text:
This is a derivative of the filament spindle made by Erik on Thingiverse. This is designed to operate along side the Makerbot rather then the RepRap. Because the Makerbot Cupcake CNC does not have the same structure that the RepRap does, the original design does not work. By attaching the stand we now have a standard spindle which works with any system. Problems that still need to be addressed:
  • Spindle spins so freely that the filament itself would probably unwind itself slowly. In the future i would like to add a screw that can be tightened which adds friction to the sides. Keeping the spindle from spinning 'too' freely.
  • The Spindle is slightly underweight and with enough lateral force could topple. To address this issue simply attach something heavy to the base. Or add an additional acrylic piece perpendicular to the current stand to increase the base size.

Assembly instructions still to come.
I personally cut the M8 rod with Bolt Cutters.  Then filed down the ends with, you guessed it, a file.
Also it may be preferred to cut the brackets which encapsulate the bearings using thinner acrylic.  This will make it weaker but will also make tightening the M8 nuts easier around the bearings.
Be sure to play with the files before cutting them out in Acrylic. They may need some clean up after import.

description.text: An extension to a standard dishrack to improve the drainage angle.

The sink in my kitchen has an annoying lip around the side. In addition to making it hard to clean the counter, this lip prevents a normal dishrack from draining properly as the angle built into the bottom of the rack is not steep enough. These feet clip onto the bottom of the rack, raising it up and providing a better drainage angle.

title: Focustab for LEICA SUMMICRON-M 50 mm f/2

description.text: This ring with focustab slides onto the lens and stays firmly in place. Inspired by original focustabs on other Leica lenses.
Best results with 0.1 layer height.

comments.text: Hello!  I love the idea of this accessory.  I printed one following your instructions, but it was just a hair too small.  It would not fit on the lens, and when I really tried to get it on, it cracked.  I used ABS.  Is your design best used with PLA?  Any assistance would be much appreciated.  My friend has this lens, and I want to make a working print of this for him.  Thank you!  :)
comments.author: MusashiX2

comments.text: Hello! When using ABS I would recommend scaling it up 1% - I used PLA and it worked great from the first print. Also please note that short portion of the focustag should face out from the camera - like show on the picture - it wont fit when installed other way around. It is a tight fit, but when all the groves line up it should just slide onto the lens. Also print on the lowest setting you can :)
comments.author: MusashiX2

title: One Up / Two Up Slim Bowden X Carriage

description.text:
Since bowden systems don't have the motor on the carriage, I thought it would be a good idea to make it slimmer for extra x-axis distance.

NOTE: X AXIS WILL HAVE TO BE INVERTED TO USE THIS.
I decided to put the belt tensioner on the bottom so I can put the mounting holes on top for more z axis travel. I included the source file for this part if anyone wants to change that.

Known Issue: The fan support may bump into the bolt that holds the right x-carriage belt bearing. I will try to update this part to prevent that.

For the extra parts, such as the fan duct, visit macattak's page and download them from there. Since this is a remix, all his parts will still work with this; I just don't want to upload parts I didn't edit or recreate from scratch.

Update: Added ubis mount. Didn't fix the issue of bumping into the bolt yet though.

NOTE: X AXIS WILL HAVE TO BE INVERTED TO USE THIS.
Requires 2 LM8UU bearings.

Changing the orientation before printing might help with the mounts.

title: 4" Display Base for a Glass Dome

description.text: I realize this is a very specific model, but I didn't find much online. I print all of my bases for display domes and now anyone can print one. This has much more character than a disc with a groove routed into it. It will fit a 4" dia. glass display dome.

The only piece you might not figure out is the riser. It fits under the tray to help support it. PLA likes to move or sag with time and weight and this will help keep planes true.
Domes vary and aren't truly round. You may have to scale the model up or down slightly after measuring the interior diameter of your dome.

author: Simonarri

description.text: This is the top cover for an iRobot Roomba 500/600 robot vacuum cleaner, or iRobot Create 2 mobile robot. This version has an opening allowing you to access the DIN-8 serial port for programming the Roomba with your PC or Arduino.

This is an OpenSCAD file, so you can remix it with whatever attachments you want. My printer had a hard time making the four clips strong enough, so they tend to break off, but after several test prints the geometry is close enough the cover stays on regardless.

You'll need a big printer, since the cover is 30cm (1 foot) across. It uses about 70 grams of filament.

The design is derived from Andreas Weidlinger (AndiTheBest)'s [iRobot Roomba 650 cover for Roowifi].(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:738942)

This modified version:

  • Translate comments and variable names to English
  • Replace Roowifi slot with a round hole for the serial port
  • Add parameters for wall heights and overall thicknesses
  • Add lip around inside of handle
  • Add fillet (bevel) around inside and outside walls
  • Correct overall scaling to match real Roomba

No Fins

Other versions:
Version 1 - No fins - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:965108 (this model)
Version 2 - Fins - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:996689
Version 2a - Small - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:996689 (same diameter as DeWalt)
Version 3 - Pen Holder - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1006663
Version 4 - Drag Knife Mount - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1551921

I remade this thing to my liking. This is a remake and I give props to mathesonmd for the initial design. This is used to reduce the amount of dust spread around by the CNC machine. Instead of blowing air straight down onto the product, it will send it out the side instead.

I updated to v2. I moved the screw holes out a couple mm so they line up better.

  • I thinned the bottom layer by 1mm so that I get more wrench on the chuck nut.
  • I flanged out the LED holes so more light comes out.
  • I reduced the height of the screw mount section so that everything fit flat on the 611.
  • I set countersinks for the screws so you can use the original screws that come with the 611.
  • I chopped one side off to get better access to the lock button.

This was my first use of OnShape.com CAD which is awesome... you should try it out (it's free).

I printed this out with 100% fill. I did this just in case I needed to hone out the screw holes.

I used Hatchbox Black PLA on M3D Micro.

This is a little adapter that allows you to attach point and shoot cameras containing a tripod socket to a GoPro mount. I made this so I could easily interchange between my Canon S100 and my GoPro on my drone when doing aerial photography.

What you will need:
1 x 1/4 by 1 inch UNc 20 hexhead bolt

I got mine from Bunnings but you can get them here as well:
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/Qty-1-Hex-Head-Bolt-1-4-UNC-x-1-Zinc-High-Tensile-Grade-8-Screw-BSW-ZP-/231562288636?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_15&hash=item35ea301dfc

Printing:
I printed this on my Replicator 2 at 20% infill, 0.3mm layer height and 3 walls.

Assembly:
The part is designed so when you slot the bolt into the hexagonal recess in the correct orientation it will screw completely into the tripod screw socket (5mm deep) and finish with the mount facing perpendicular with the screen.

If you find that you screw the part all the way into the camera and it is offset by some multiple of 30 degrees, unscrew the part and rotate the bolt in the hexagonal recess. Try screwing it into the camera again and see if it lines up flush this time. Rinse and repeat until it mounts perfectly.

If you're tripod hole is not 5mm deep or it simply won't line up you can try putting washers or double sided tape in-between the camera body and part to adjust the angle.

This fidget keyring is a simple design using a 3 gear chain to do nothing but entertain its user. Turn the small gear and watch the other gears turn!

Requires 3x 10-12mm m3 bolts and 3x m3 nuts.

Revised Base & Top - moved both 30T Gears 0.5mm further from the 15T gear for easier spin.

Revised both gears - bored to 5.5mm for extra clearance / easier spin.

I've printed this on 0.15mm layer height using ABS on an UP! Plus 1.
0.25 layers would work well as a lot of the clearances are 0.5mm.

Press the nuts into their holes using plyers.

I had to shave some excess ABS from the axels with a scalpel form where the layers met printing the circles in order to allow for an easier spin of the gears.

title: G-Code cleaning routine for a cold pull using nylon

description.text:
Don't use the STL -- It's just there so Thingiverse is happy.
Tested with Marlin firmware, but no special codes are used.
Use Nylon filament; Taulman is best http://amzn.to/2GC3fHB -- I use 618.
Each line is documented

I was tired of the manual steps, so I coded up this routine:
Go to 230c, extrude 30 (to load filament -- Taulman Nylon 618)
Go to 100c, while extruding another 30 very slowly (to keep it solid as the temperature falls if your nylon isn't perfectly dry).
End...

Then you manually release the filament drive and pull the filament out the top; it will carry the gunk with it. Repeat until you get a clean pull.

To use:

  1. Remove old filament (may need to preheat to do so)
  2. Load Nylon (or at least get it ready; see 3b)
  3. Execute g-code; it will
    3.a. Heat to 230c (where nylon extrudes freely on my printer)
    3.b. Extrude 30 cm to complete the loading and squirt a little out
    3.c. Cool to 100c while extruding another 30cm very slowly
    The printer should stop extruding at some point because it got too cold; this is to prevent puffs of steam from messing things up if your nylon isn't 100% dry.

Now, snap off the extruded part below the nozzle, then release the drive and pull the filament out of the top (this will require a good bit of force if you're not using a lubricated nozzle). The nylon will trap and hold the misc junk that was clogging the nozzle or making it difficult to feed.

Snip off the end and repeat as necessary to get a clean result (if I've had real issues it's taken 3 cleaning cycles to come clean). If you see the wick end, that means that the nozzle is completely clear and you can lubricate it if you wish (I recommend WS2 or HBn spray).

this is an OpenScad script that will create Domino tiles for you! you only need to specify the size of each tile, the maximum 'eyes' you want (most common = 6; max. supported by now = 9) and the number of tiles to skip (for bigger sizes that cannot be created in a single run). the main goal of this script is the placement of the domino tiles and calculation of the needed eyes-count on each single tile...
the outline of one tile isn't optimal yet - you are very welcome to create better ones (those are the modules one_brick to create the outline and eye to create one single eye at the top of the script).
[btw: the small pieces in the first picture are from an earlier/simpler design; I didn't tried the actual design with the small pieces yet] because OpenScad does neither have working variables nor allows recursive module calls, the maximum amount of eyes is '9' (plus: the eye-placement for big counts like 12 or 18 could be messy).

• OpenScad: load domino.scad and call build_dominos(width,length,height,max_eyes,skip); with the arguments of your choice
  • OpenScad: render (F6)
  • OpenScad: export as .stl
  • import into ReplicatorG
  • print
  • repeat for bigger tiles...
    • note: if you create dominos which cannot be made in a single turn, the script will tell you, what value you'd need for the next turn:
    "to generate next block, skip = nn", so you don't need to count the already printed pieces ;-)
  • I marked that with a red rectangle in the 2nd and 3rd OpenScad screenshot, a bit small I must admire :-/ but at least you have an idea where to look for that hint...
    • I have included a single .stl for rather small pieces (10x20x4mm; 6-eyes)
    plus all the needed .stl's to print more useable ones (20x30x6mm; 9-eyes)
    beware those .stl's are for the HBP!, if you are running the ABP, you may want to adjust the max. print area, since the script is using the full area (see second picture)!

description.text: test cones by Bill [created on 3DTin]

Create epic castles, build awesome 3D tessellations, and battle other sand kingdoms in full out catapult warfare.

Thingiversity Math Challenge: Build A Castle.

  • Build Egypt, build Rome, or build your own kingdom! This set of objects is a must print if you plan on going to the beach any time soon. It comprises three unique castle molds, an adjustable catapult for Castle Battle games, flags and banners for decoration or game objectives, three key sculpting tools for custom builds, a set of tetrahedron and pyramid tessellation molds for tessellating in three dimensions and creating large pyramids, and a brand new arch creator mold!

:: UPDATE NOTES ::

8/16/15 - NEW MOLD - Added the roman Arches Mold. See more below.

8/13/15 - Reduced the mass of the Fort mold by 29.6% ! (still produces the same sand castle), also added game dice.

8/12/15 - Rearranged the pyramid tessellator to accommodate smaller print beds

8/3/2017 - Fixed potential watertight issue with catapult

8/3/2017 - Fixed Tetrahedron tessellator not laying flat

:: THE GOLDEN TESSELLATORS ::

How big can you build it? Mathematically speaking, the limit does not exist!
It's no surprise that the ancient Egyptians were some math wizards, after thousands of years, their amazing monuments still stand.
This kit includes two dynamic sand molds that create tetrahedron and pyramid sand blocks. When stacked in the right manner, they tessellate in three dimensions (see picture). Moist sand can stack on itself remarkably well, even at angles close to 90 degrees perpendicular from the ground. When tessellating with these molds to create a larger pyramid, the graduating slope is about 55 degrees which allows you to build incredibly large pyramids.
Use these Golden Tessellators in a Castle Battle game as an game objective or just make giant awesome pyramids!

  • If you would like to know how many blocks are in a pyramid of height n, use this equation: (2n - 1)^2 The small exploded pyramid has a height of 2 tessellator blocks, therefore it contains 9 blocks. The large pyramid in pictures has a height of 15... that equates to 841 blocks!

( Fun Fact ! - Did you that the ancient Egyptians were able to accomplish the seemingly impossible task of constructing the famous pyramids by moving the massive blocks on a sled that moved over wet sand? Dampening the sand in front of the primitive device reduces friction on the sled, making it easier to operate. Who would have though it? Sand and water. I bet they could make some great sandcastles too! )

:: ROMAN ARCHES ::

The Romans used mathematics for its practical applications and with brute force created some of the most astonishing structures the world has ever seen. By using an arch design, tall structures could be made even taller. The roman aqueducts and Colosseum were designed with the inherently strong support of arches, and still stand today!

The new Arch Mold allows you create your own bit of Rome. After the two part mold is fitted together on a sturdy base of sand, plop some muddy/wet sand in between pat it in until it is dry and hard. After a few times plopping and patting the lower half of the mold can be removed, followed by the upper half to reveal your solid Roman arch. Arrange sever arches in a line to make an aqueduct, can it transport water?

( Fun Fact ! - Did you know that the recipe for concrete was forgotten after the fall of the Roman Empire in the 5th century and not rediscovered until the 18th century? What a bummer! Find your perfect sand recipe and don't forget it! )

:: CASTLE BATTLES ::

Making beautiful castles is fun, but not nearly as fun as destroying them! Have fun with it in this game I like to call "Castle Battles Classic"

1) To get started, print out the Omni tool, assemble a catapult, and head to a beach. On the side of the Omni Tool there are two wedges that protrude. You can drag these wedges across a flat area of the beach to make parallel lines in the sand. Make more lines perpendicular to those you have a nice Cartesian grid with square units that measure 6 x 6 inches.

2) If your playing with a friend, make sand castles or sand kingdoms on opposite sides of the grid using the castle molds or the toolkit.

3) Add flags and banners to the castles or battlefield as player pieces or objective pieces.

4) Game on! After determining who goes first, roll a die. The player can now do only one of three things, move his/her catapult an amount of units equivalent to half the roll, and rounding down if the roll is odd (i.e. the player rolls a 5, he/she may move left right up or down only 2 units, a roll of 6 allows 3 movements, and a roll of 1 allows no movements), fire from the catapult a number of times equivalent to the roll, or add/fortify a structure on their side of the grid only if a 6 is rolled.

5) If a player launches a projectile into the grid unit of the other players catapult (or catapult placeholder) the opponent must reset their catapult to the starting unit.

6) Winning the game: the player who has the least amount of damage after X amount of rounds wins the game, or the player who has knocked down all of their opponents banners wins the game.

Game Notes:

  • Catapult power is adjusted by raising or lowing the rubber band's anchor points along the hooked front rails, and can be done so at any point in the game.
  • Marbles make for great projectiles, but don't aim them at your friends, animals, or your friends animals!
  • Flags make for great place holders for catapults if you catapult supply is low. If your game mode allows it, use multiple flags per player to act as different offensive positions to switch from.
  • The grid battle field allows for up to four players if you dedicate each side to a different castle or kingdom.
  • This game is not the only game you have to play, make your own or make additions to these rules and put them in the comments, I'd love to hear them!

:: A Final Note From the Creator ::

Hello Thingiverse community! This is my first ever thingiverse submission which I entered for a challenge back in 2015 but did not win. I noticed that a few people were interested in it so i try to keep it up to date if mistakes are found. I hope you like it. Printing all these parts is not easy for my as i do not have a printer of my own, but I will try to get them printed and upload pictures as soon as i can. If you have any complaints about any of the objects, please let me know and I'll try to make corrections right away. Feel free to ask questions or give suggestions.

...stay tuned for possible expansion packs....

-All objects were created in Google Sketchup.
-A majority of the objects are very printer friendly any require no supports. I would recommend using supports for the Omni-tool, the Scooping tool, and the Wall mold.
-After printing the Tessellators, use a short bit of coat-hanger rod as the axis on which the side flaps can hinge.

description.text:
If you're like me, you want to see what's going on. Unfortunately, the PB Play's safety shroud keeps most of that a mystery until you've printed at least 10 layers - and let's be honest, that's not so great.

The Printrbot Play Fan Mount version 1.0 is a minimalistic fan mount that opens the doors to the mysterious happenings behind the mask...or in this case, shroud - and best of all, it's a single piece that you can print on you Printrbot Play!

I would recommend printing at 100% fill. I did the prototype at .15 mm layer thickness, but decide what's right for you. Also, lower your print speed. I went down to 10mm/sec due to some weirdness that was happening at 50.

I've attached a CURA saved model (.amf) file so it should be perfectly oriented and ready to go. There's also an stl if you can't open the amf file for some reason. Also, this is version 1.0. It works great, but I'm always making refinements on my designs - so there is more to come. Stay tuned!
Designed in SolidWorks 2014

title: Super Hexy Raspberry Pi 2 Case & Camera for Replicator 2

description.text:
Hexy Raspberry Pi 2 Model B case, with lots of hexy octo-vents. Connectors and SD card openings, except expansion header and the display header. I didn't need need those for my Astroprint.

But wait, there's more! It has attachments to mount this to your OEM Makerbot Replicator 2 arms. I will revise once I get my aluminum arm upgrade, one day.

It is the Thing that keeps on giving, you also get a super adjustable camera mount, with adjustability in the Y axis, Z axis and a pan axis. Enough adjustment to keep you away from trouble and still get the shot.

I use this for my Astroprint setup.

NOTE: Photos show alpha unit. All improvements were added to the design and the beta design is what you download here. The alpha unit works well enough for me, I don't need to print beta. But, if you look a the photos, you will see differences from the design files.

You will need some nuts, screws, standoffs and of course a Raspberry Pi 2 Model B and Pi Camera 1.3.

The camera mount is simple, just slide it into the slots. It's not a complete camera enclosure, just a simple open mount.

The standoffs need to be 1/4" OD with a #4-40 female on each end. The length needed is about 2.5", but 2" or 3" will work.

The unit is made with a combination of #4-40 x 1/4" and 1/2" socket head caps screws or pan head, and a 4 x #4-40 x 7/8" flat head screws. Don't forget the hex nuts.

You will have to tap a few holes with a #4-40 tap.

When assembled, unit slides on and off the Rep 2 arms with ease. Stays in place while printing.

Mini laser cutter/engraver created from parts salvaged from CD-ROM drives, a DVD-Rom burner and a 3.5" floppy drive. It was inspired by this Pocket laser engraver by Groover. If you want to build one read his Instructable for details.

It is powered by a Arduino Pro Mini running GRBL an open source g-code-parser and CNC milling controller. The CD-ROM drive stepper motors are driven by Easy Driver Stepper Motor Drivers. The laser is a 650nm 400mW red laser diode from a DVD-Burner in a Aixiz module driven by a Constant current laser driver. It has enough power to cut craft foam and colored paper (sticky notes) and will engrave wood.

I've included the OpenSCAD source for the frame, print bed and mounts since you will probably have to modify them to fit the parts you have. It was printed with a Printrbot Simple Metal with heated bed.

The video is of the previous version of the laser cutter that had a wood frame that I could never quite get square and gave me the excuse to buy a 3d printer.

Updated Video of current version cutting a SVG out of a Post-It Note.
Printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal with heated bed. I used 5 top layers, 5 bottom layers and 5 perimeters with 30% honeycomb infill. The frame requires support and the rest of the parts do not.

description.text:
Articulated action figure created with Tinkerplay.

The character body segment files are exported directly from the app's built-in library of interchangeable parts and thus design credit goes to the Autodesk/Tinkerplay team. Exact license terms are unclear but I infer them to be liberal since the point of the app is partly to download and print modified models.

I am fairly impressed with the fit and function despite printing at 0.3 mm layer height, which makes some of the ball and socket joints a bit coarse. I doubt the joints will retain their initial firmness after repeated posing, as a few have already become more prone to popping apart, but it is nonetheless clear that these are thoughtfully designed pieces.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

The design of this violin is not my own. I downloaded the files from http://community.thefoundry.co.uk/discussion/topic.aspx?f=4&t=61185 and am sharing them here.

I printed all the parts in PLA, and the strings in ABS. I scaled down the the parts so that the biggest part (the top plate) just fit my printer (Flashforge Dreamer). I printed at 0.2 layer resolution.

I did's use the string model, but instead made my own strings from ABS. To do this, I ran my extruder (the 'load filament' function on my printer) and pulled the extrusion out walking across the room at different speeds to get varying string thicknesses. The E string on the right side is the thinnest, with the G string on the left the thickest. I drilled holes through the pegs to insert the strings. I made notches on the bridge for the strings to sit, like a real violin.

The chin rest support didn't seem to be long enough to go around the edge of the violin, so I just cut and glued it in place.

The bridge is not glued down, just held up with the strings like a real violin.

description.text:
WORK IN PROGRESS! MAY OR MAY NOT PRINT! MAY OR MAY NOT WORK AS A COOKIE CUTTER!

This is an improvement to the Minion Cookie Cutter by tetens.

It pushes the facial features, the neckline, and the chest element, down by 3mm to help it work better as a cookie cutter. It also makes the arms fatter, and gets rid of a little of the armpit area to help the arms stay with the body!

Use a sugar cookie dough that is stiff enough to cut well or you will lose parts! Dough needs to be thick enough so that the features are imprinted. As you can see some of mine were not thick enough.

I used a .25mm nozzle to print this so you will likely need to cut down your extrusion width to something small. The walls are as thin as they are because of the way I hacked the original design. Handle is optional but can be epoxied to the cutter. Print using PLA for food safe use!

title: Half-Life 2 Poison Headcrab: Low and High Resolution

description.text: Printed the regular Headcrab available here and I had to have the Poison Headcrab. Unable to find it anywhere here I went ahead and searched the net for him. I took the time to clean him up, opened up the file and started deleting the skeleton rig and triangles made for the little hairs that we obviously can't print and also made a high poly version by subdividing and smoothing a few times. Still trying to look for the best position to print this guy on my own printer. Post your methods/positions you guys found is best for printing this guy, legs on mine keep failing.

comments.text:
When printing things with a smooth shell but also detailed underside (I think of mirelurks from Fallout 4) I found it best to render them upside down so that the shell has all the supports. Not the under side which holds a lot of detail. This way it's easier to remove the support materials from the shell and not risk snapping limbs on the opposite side.
If I get around to making one I'll share it (^_^)

title: Anti-Glare SHADE for IKEA Harte LED Lamp

description.text:
The IKEA Harte LED lamp is cheap, cool, portable and runs off USB. The neck has some range of movement and the LED panel can be rotated. Only problem is, if you use it as a desk lamp, you often catch the glare.

This slip-on shade allows you to keep the lamp out of the way, at the back of the desk, while getting full lighting without the glare.

Designed with raised arms to provide heat ventilation, for prolonged use.

title: Kossel 2020 mains inlet and electronics front panel

description.text:
This is the front panel I use on my 2020 Kossel for mounting the mains inlet connector, fuse, on/off switch, and the Duet electronics. It includes access holes for the Reset and Erase buttons of the Duet 0.8.5 or the new Duet WiFi board, along with a thin section for the LEDs on those versions of the Duet to shine through. It can also be used with a Duet 0.6 board. Pick the version with WiFi or the version with Ethernet depending on which Duet you have.

A matching rear panel at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1617834 supports the back of the board and a 40mm fan for cooling the stepper driver chips in the confined space under the bed. See my blog at https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com for detailed instructions.

The mains inlet parts that this design accommodates are:

  • Bulgin PX0575/15/63 low profile snap fit IEC mains inlet (Farnell 469658)
  • Panel mounting 20mm fuse holder (Farnell 9630198)
  • Arcoelectric H8553VBNAO illuminated mains switch (Farnell 150388)

The panel is a little too thick for the locking tabs of the Bulgin snap-in mains inlet to engage fully, so I used a small file to chamfer the top and bottom edges of the back of the hole until the tabs would lock in place.

You can get other IEC mains inlets that integrate the switch and the fuse, but I didn't find one that was slim enough to fit in 20mm height.

Before fitting the Duet, check that the Reset and Erase buttons sit properly in the holes provided for them, because if the panel fouls them then you might accidentally erase the firmware and need to re-flash it.

title: Fan Duct for Sarf's Groove Mount

description.text:
Finally, the fan duct has been completed. The mount are also added to the groove lock to be compatible with AndrewBCN's fan duct here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:540716 and here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:154834

The fan duct are still not tested in real world yet and how the fan duct improves the quality are unknown. This design are based on Tom Sanladerer's (I think) suggestion of a good fan duct design having the air to blow from more than one side so the printed object won't get warped on one side. The design is quite weird since it is designed to sit in front of the existing e3d v6 30mm fan by covering it there and you are unable to see your hot end/nozzle after mounting this.

The groove lock are compatible with the previous versions, from v1 to v3, and has been trimmed a little from 13mm to about 11mm thick (height) so it won't obstruct or tilted the e3d 30mm fan with the mount.

The big object is visualization of how it should be mounted and there's no need to print, only the other 3 objects are needed

Credit to AndrewBCN for the very short arm design

Disadvantages:
Due to the original design of v1-v3, when rotating the 30mm fan to the sides underneath the mount, it will be tilted and I personally think this is not a good idea because of the mount being forced to expand than it normally wold (tilted when it shouldn't) and slightly compromised airflow to cool the heat sink. In order to rotate/remove/change/maintain the hot end, there's no other way than to dismount the fan duct first before releasing the groove lock screw, also this design are for m4 screws only based on v2

Assembled.stl is just example how it will be mounted especially on my setup for low profile.

Print 2 arm short, the new groove lock and fan duct (rotate them)

It is recommended to use M4x38mm so that when mounting the groove mount, the nut will be pushed back at the x carriage, and it will lock with the screw

Everything uses M4 based and currently its fixed to M4 only except mounting the fan through the arm, that one uses M3 scrws

comments.text: Very impressive design! Good work!
comments.author: AndrewBCN

comments.text: Thank you, I still haven't tested this as I'm away from my printer for another week. Hopefully this fan duct would have a great impact on prints
comments.author: AndrewBCN

author: andybigidea

description.text:
Rumba output test gcode

Turns on FAN0, FAN1, HB, HE0, HE1 & HE2 for one second. Output led's should blink.

Then it will sequentially run all motors in one direction, then the other.

During this test, acceleration and steps per mm are changed for all motors so make sure to reset your printer after executing this file.

The dummy.scad file is just a dummy because thingiverse is a restricted verse
Just run the gcode file with your Marlin compatible firmware on your Rumba board

comments.text:
Hello,
I was trying to upload the Marlin firmware to the RUMBA and I found out that Arduino IDE showed me this problem: " avrdude: stk500v2_ReceiveMessage(): timeout". Have you ever had this problem? How did you solve it??
Thank you very much,
Francisco

Same rims as in these 2 kits
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:526969
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:964789

but these rims go directly onto the axle without the 12mm hex hub nut, using a longer pin (diam 2x16mm)

Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament.

Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this:

This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design:

•The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc.

description.text: Cookie cutter made for AACIMP Summer School using http://www.cookiecaster.com/

Workbech PCB holder, similar size as "Weller ESF-120" which costs ~$50. To make this one it will cost you ~$5, you can easily buy all metal parts in your local DIY store as it's made from largely available components.

Bill of material:

  • 2x 30cm M8 threaded rod
  • 8x M8 nut
  • 2x M8 large washer
  • 3x M6 large washer
  • 1x M6 washer
  • 1x M6 or M8 spring
  • 1x M6x30 hex bolt
  • 1x M6x90 hex bolt (length depends on your spring length)
  • 2x M6 nut with nylon
  • 1x M4x20 bolt
  • 1x M4 nut
  • 1x M4 washer
  • 4x small pieces of school rubber (to prevent moving on the bench)
  • piece of sponge/foam to hold components with arm

To print

  • 1x Frame
  • 1x Frame Notch
  • 2x PCB Holder
  • 4x Nut Holder
  • 2x Nut Dome
  • 1x Shim
  • 1x Knob Handle
  • 1x Arm
  • 1x Arm Sponge

If you wish to edit source, this library is used for bolts&nuts

I'm the beginner for OpenGL programming, it's not comfortable to view the model.
If you have any idea for improving this application, comment to this article please. Known problem: It doesn't work with some complex STL file. Maybe out of memory error. Updated 2013 Feb. 6:
Now, I published this project as open source. The source code is available at github repository.
https://github.com/kshoji/STLViewer

Just access to the Android Market(below), and install it into your Android phone.
https://market.android.com/details?id=jp.kshoji.stlviewer You can download the STL file with Opera or some browser.
Default browser with my DesireHD, couldn't save STL file from thingiverse. I don't know why. After downloaded the file, then open with the application.
Tap folder icon, and you can see SD card directory. Then choose STL file.

The original printable DIY template could be found on my Etsy store:

https://www.etsy.com/shop/MushMool

The number of the polygons have been reduced with Meshlab, than I used Rhino with T-Splines to define some key features of the object. Later I have used it to make a ready to make papercraft model. I used Pepakura for that. If anyone is interested I could send him the link on Etsy.

title: 20x20mm aluminum profile microswitch holder for Kossel Max

description.text:
This an customized version of the standard endstop holder for Kossel Max. As I own a lot of microswitches instead of the standard ones, and there's no available holder, I decided to design my own model. It hooks on the aluminum profile and holds tight. No need for volts or nuts.
Pictures pending!

UPDATED (29-9-2015)

I've noticed it's hard to fit the microswitch into the holder. So I modified it to be easier to assemble and a little bit tinnier too.
Source SW file is included

title: Lulzbot TAZ bearing / bushing holders with tightening clamps

description.text:
Standard TAZ bearing holders, with an addition for clamping them around the IGUS bushings.

The IGUS bushings have a tendency to wear or become loose, allowing for play in the axes. Hopefully this will be a simple solution to this problem. I have not tested this part as of yet, but it seems to work. I'll post results when I do print + test it.

To use these clamps, you'll need m3 screws that are greater 12mm in length. You'll also need m3 nuts for the m3 screws.
For each double bearing holder: 2x m3 nuts + 2x m3 screws
For each single bearing holder: 1x m3 nut + 1x m3 screw

I plan to print these with 3+ shells and > 30% infill @ any layer height.

Look to description for parts needed.

comments.text: Did this help your problem?  I have a Taz 5 less than a month old, with excessive slop and backlash in the bushings.
comments.author: StorageJarett

comments.text: Can't say I've gotten around to trying these. I'd contact Lulzbot if that were the case with such a young printer. You can also replace your IGUS bushings.
comments.author: StorageJarett

title: roijeric's Printrbot Simple Spool Holder modified for smaller spools

description.text:
I wrote an OpenSCAD script that cuts up the central part of roijeric's spool holder and moves the corners closer, so it can be used with spools smaller than the original 72mm. The "length" of the spool holder can also be adjusted (might be necessary for spools with smaller radius I guess).

I have included an STL for 40mm spools, slightly shortened to fit a small printer.

The feet are unchanged from the original; I have included the STL files for completeness.

Put Spool_Holder_Connector.STL in the same folder as Spool_Holder_Connector_Parametric.scad.

Adjust the values:
spool_w: spool width
spool_d: spool diameter (not used in the final part, just for visualization purposes)
desired_h: length of the spool holder

For small values, the connecting struts may be too small or disappear completely; feel free to implement your own struts if this happens.

You need 2 of each type of feet and 1 connector to make a complete spool holder.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing! Looks great.
comments.author: roijeric

title: Nuts and Bolts v1.95 OpenSCAD library

description.text:
A quite simple OpenSCAD library.

EDIT2:
Hi again. Added a new bolt type.
Next version will include Customizer version. I swear.

EDIT:
Hello there, I'm on vacation but still working on this library.
Turned to version 1.91 from the v0.9 published before.
I included the "threads.scad" lib directly into mine library to make it easier to work with.
I've added a lot of features, and a new module called washer().
Cleaned up a little the code and commented some lines, but not everything, sorry.
Added a disclaimer, some examples for EVERY module and a full rendering of any bit you can create with this library and OpenSCAD.
Just to remind you, thanks to Dan Kirshner, threads created with its and mine library are mechanically correct and adhere to the ANSI and ISO standards.
Next version will support MakerBot Customizer and some new module bits.

Anyway, take a look at the code to learn how to make perfects nuts and bolts that will flawlessly fit in to your own designs.

It gives you the ability to create nuts, bolts and grubs with metric and imperial pitches and measures.

IF U SELECT IMPERIAL U HAVE TO PUT NUMBERS IN THE IMPERIAL WAY (EG 1/8, 3/8) and not mixing types in the variables.

Examples in the SCAD file.

Use it your way, but if u modify the code you HAVE to leave my copyright AS IT IS as mentioned in the GPL3 licence.

Thanks to Dan Kirshner - dan_k[email protected] for his "threads.scad" library, included in this thing.

Just put an INCLUDE into your .scad file and use it as any other OpenSCAD library, or set the render variable to 1 and comment out bits you don't need to render and have fun.

I use it to make boolean operations over my designs and make space to REAL nut and bolts.

If you want to print threads, bolts and washers, remember to use the right material, like Taulmann 618 or 645 to make them strong enough.

comments.text: One of the most useful libraries for OpenSCAD - saved me countless hours and improved the accuracy of my designs. Thanks for the great work.
comments.author: llmora

comments.text:
Doh. I searched thingiverse for nuts_and_bolts to find a replacement for the MCAD library and didn't find anything. I ended up making this:

title: Storage box for mini playing cards

description.text:
my kids have several of these mini-playing card kits - Uno, Apples to Apples, etc. The little cardboard box they come in lasted about 10 min so I whipped this up to help keep them from getting lost. Printed in ABS with 2 perimeters and .3 layer height. .5mm tolerance between the two pieces so you may need to sand a few rough spots. Should scale pretty easily if you need it to.

***updated top with scallop so you can easily remove even if your kids press it together without cards in it :(

title: Universal-ish spool hub for Hatchbox and Taulman

description.text:
A friend asked me to make a spool hub that fits Taulman spools for his dry box. Sure! I said. And then discovered that the hub center for a Taulman spool is about 19mm. Doh! So I came up with this. Used the area needed to support the bearing to work on a Hatchbox spool.

Made to fit a 608 bearing.

My friend was so impressed with the turn around time of his taulman hub, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:965837, that he said, "hey you're getting good at this!"
To which I replied, "Yeah, I feel like I'm getting the hang of this."
His next response was, "It would be cool if this looked like the rims on my car..."
I should have said, Challenge accepted!
Instead I asked for a picture.
A bit of messing about, and I came up with this. To which he replied, "You are mad."

Yes, thank you, I know... Now, it's not an exact match to the wheel, but it's a semi-ok homage without any real 3D modeling being done.

Made to fit a 608 bearing.
